articles.headline: Militants Seize Americans and Other Hostages in Algeria
articles.snippet: The State Department said Americans were among hostages captured by Islamist extremists in Algeria on Wednesday, in what the attackers called retaliation for France’s intervention in Mali.
articles.abstract: The State Department said Americans were among hostages captured by Islamist extremists in Algeria on Wednesday, in what the attackers called retaliation for France’s intervention in Mali.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — The French military assault on Islamist extremists in Mali escalated into a potentially much broader North African conflict on Wednesday when, in retribution, armed attackers in unmarked trucks seized an internationally managed natural gas field in neighboring Algeria and took at least 20 foreign hostages, including Americans.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Scott Sayare

articles.headline: Obama to ‘Put Everything I’ve Got’ Into Gun Control
articles.snippet: President Obama on Wednesday unveiled plans to introduce legislation by next week that includes a ban on assault weapons, limits on high-capacity magazines and other steps.
articles.abstract: President Obama on Wednesday unveiled plans to introduce legislation by next week that includes a ban on assault weapons, limits on high-capacity magazines and other steps.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four days before taking the oath of office, President Obama on Wednesday staked the beginning of his second term on an uphill quest to pass the broadest gun control legislation in a generation.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Spicing Up a Ho-Hum Tech Show
articles.snippet: This year’s Consumer Electronics Show didn’t have a lot to write home about, but there was some action courtesy of Daxton Blackthorne.
articles.abstract: This year’s Consumer Electronics Show didn’t have a lot to write home about, but there was some action courtesy of Daxton Blackthorne.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hi boss! I’m back from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. You assigned me to report on what’s new and exciting, but I have some bad news. The answer is: almost nothing.

articles.headline: Germany to Move 674 Tons of Gold
articles.snippet: Two-thirds of Germany’s gold reserves is stored in Paris, London and New York. The German central bank, responding to a public outcry over accountability, is going to repatriate some of the gold.
articles.abstract: Two-thirds of Germany’s gold reserves is stored in Paris, London and New York. The German central bank, responding to a public outcry over accountability, is going to repatriate some of the gold.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Nearly half of Germany’s gold reserves are held in a vault at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York — billions of dollars worth of postwar geopolitical history squirreled away for safe keeping below the streets of Lower Manhattan.

articles.headline: F.A.A. Grounds U.S.-Operated Boeing 787s
articles.snippet: The directive applies to United Airlines, the only American carrier using the new plane, after several safety incidents in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: The directive applies to United Airlines, the only American carrier using the new plane, after several safety incidents in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration said Wednesday that it was grounding all Boeing 787s operated by United States carriers until it can determine what caused a new type of battery to catch fire on two planes in nine days.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew, Jad Mouawad and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: F.D.A. Seeks to Tighten Regulation of All-Metal Hip Implants
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. is proposing rules that could stop manufacturers from selling a type of artificial hip that is failing early in many patients.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. is proposing rules that could stop manufacturers from selling a type of artificial hip that is failing early in many patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: After an estimated 500,000 patients in the United States have received a type of artificial hip that is failing early in many cases, the Food and Drug Administration is proposing rules that could stop manufacturers from selling such implants.

articles.headline: U.S. Sees Hazy Threat From Mali Militants
articles.snippet: The rush of  violent events has masked the fact that officials in Washington still have only an impressionistic understanding of the militant groups that have established a safe haven in Mali.
articles.abstract: The rush of  violent events has masked the fact that officials in Washington still have only an impressionistic understanding of the militant groups that have established a safe haven in Mali.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Islamic militants methodically carved out a base in the desert of northern Mali over the past year, officials in Washington, Paris and African capitals struggling with military plans to drive the Islamists out of the country agreed on one principle: African troops, not European or American soldiers, would fight the battle of Mali.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Report Details Missteps in Trading at JPMorgan
articles.snippet: An internal report written by a management task force pointed to widespread failures regarding a bad bet on credit derivatives that cost JPMorgan Chase more than $6 billion.
articles.abstract: An internal report written by a management task force pointed to widespread failures regarding a bad bet on credit derivatives that cost JPMorgan Chase more than $6 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long seen as one of the most careful banks on Wall Street, JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday drew back a curtain on a rare breakdown, showing traders acting on their own and concealing losses while managers seemingly turned a blind eye.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: JPMorgan’s Board Uses a Pay Cut as a Message
articles.snippet: The action was said to be a message that the board of JPMorgan Chase was a strong watchdog over the nation’s largest bank.
articles.abstract: The action was said to be a message that the board of JPMorgan Chase was a strong watchdog over the nation’s largest bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after the markets closed on Tuesday afternoon, an emissary from JPMorgan Chase’s board of directors walked two flights down to the 48th-floor corner office of the bank’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, to deliver a stark message. The board had voted to slash Mr. Dimon’s annual compensation for 2012 by half.

articles.headline: Next Made-in-China Boom: College Graduates
articles.snippet: China is making a huge investment in its universities, hoping to leverage its enormous population into 195 million college graduates by the end of the decade.
articles.abstract: China is making a huge investment in its universities, hoping to leverage its enormous population into 195 million college graduates by the end of the decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANYA, China — Zhang Xiaoping’s mother dropped out of school after sixth grade. Her father, one of 10 children, never attended.

articles.headline: Algerian Troops Attack Site to End Hostage Standoff
articles.snippet: Hours after Algerian forces raided a gas facility, there was still no official word on the number of hostages freed, killed or still held by their Islamist kidnappers.
articles.abstract: Hours after Algerian forces raided a gas facility, there was still no official word on the number of hostages freed, killed or still held by their Islamist kidnappers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — Without warning other governments, Algeria mounted an assault on Thursday on the heavily armed fighters holding American and other hostages at a remote Sahara gas field facility, freeing captives and killing kidnappers but leaving some hostages dead and foreign leaders scrambling to find out the fates of their citizens.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Rick Gladstone
